hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the formula for the Gauss-Seidel iteration method?

worksheet.stem:
Solve the following system using three iterations with Gauss-Seidel using overrelaxation (λ = 1.25). If necessary, rearrange the equations and show all the steps in your solution including your error estimates. At the end of the computation, compute the true error of your final results.

 

%media:formula123.mml%

 

%media:formula124.mml%

 

(Round the final answers to five decimal places and the true percent errors to two decimal places.)

 

The values of x1 = __a__ and x2 =__b__.

The values of the true percent relative error εt,1 = __c__ % and εt,2 =__d__ %.

As ordered, none of the sets are guaranteed to converge. However, if Set 1 and 2 are reordered so that they are diagonally dominant, they will converge on the solution of (1.1250, 0.9687, 1.0937), (1, 1, 1), and (0.500253, 8.000112, –6.00007) respectively.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax of the MATLAB function fsolve?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the roots of the following simultaneous nonlinear equations using the fsolve function. Employ initial guesses of x = y = 1.2. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The roots of the given equations are as follows:

x = __a__

y = __b__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Function and script

 

function f = fProb1215(x)
f=[-x(1)*x(1)+x(1)+0.5-x(2);x(1)*x(1)-x(2)-5*x(1)*x(2)];

 

clc, format compact
xguess=[1.2;1.2];
[x,fx] = fsolve(@fProb1215,xguess);
x
fx

 

Output

 

x =
    1.2333
    0.2122
fx =
   1.0e-06 *
   -0.0315
   -0.1031

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB code used to find the roots.

worksheet.stem:
Determine the roots of the given simultaneous nonlinear equations using the fsolve function. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The values of x = __a__ and y = __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Function

 

function f = fProb1216(x)
f=[(x(1)-4)*(x(1)-4)+ (x(2)-4)*(x(2)-4)-5;x(1)*x(1)+x(2)*x(2)-16];

 

Script

 

clc, format compact
xguess=[2;4];
[x,fx] = fsolve(@fProb1216,xguess);
x
fx

 

Output

 

Equation solved.

fsolve completed because the vector of function values is near zero
as measured by the default value of the function tolerance, and
the problem appears regular as measured by the gradient.

<stopping criteria details>
x =
    1.8058
    3.5692
fx =
   1.0e-11 *
    0.4936
    0.4917

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Recall the MATLAB code used to find the roots.

worksheet.stem:
Use the developed initial guesses as the starting point to determine refined estimates with the fsolve function. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The values of x = __a__ and y = __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Function and script

 

function f = fProb1217(x)
f=[x(1)^2+1-x(2);2*cos(x(1))-x(2)];

clc, format compact
x=[0:.1:2];
y1=x.^2+1;
y2=2*cos(x);
plot(x,y1,x,y2)
xlabel('x');ylabel('y');grid
xguess=[0.7;1.5];
[x,fx] = fsolve(@fProb1217,xguess);
x
fx

 

Output

 

Equation solved.

fsolve completed because the vector of function values is near zero
as measured by the default value of the function tolerance, and
the problem appears regular as measured by the gradient.

<stopping criteria details>

x =
    0.7146
    1.5107
fx =
   1.0e-07 *
    0.1962
   -0.1482

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The following chemical reactions take place in a closed system:

 

%media:formula64.mml%

 

%media:formula65.mml%

 

At equilibrium, they can be characterized by

 

%media:formula66.mml%

 

%media:formula67.mml%

 

where ci represents the concentration of constituent i. If x1 and x2 are the number of moles of C that are produced by the first and second reactions, respectively, use an approach to reformulate the equilibrium relationships in terms of the initial concentrations of the constituents. Then, solve the pair of simultaneous nonlinear equations for x1 and x2 if K1 = 4 × 10−4, K2 = 3.7 × 10−2, ca,0 = 50, cb,0 = 20, cc,0 = 5, and cd,0 = 10.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

worksheet.stem:
Use the developed initial guesses as the starting point to determine refined estimates with the fsolve function. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The values of x = __a__ and y = __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
function and script

 

function f = fProb1218(x)
f=[(5+x(1)+x(2))/(50-2*x(1)-x(2))^2/(20-x(1))-4e-4;...
(5+x(1)+x(2))/(50-2*x(1)-x(2))/(10-x(2))-3.7e-2];

clc, format compact
xguess=[3.3;2.7];
[x,fx] = fsolve(@fProb1218,xguess);
x
fx

is near zero as measured by the default value of the function tolerance, and
the problem appears regular as measured by the gradient.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The pH of the rain-water is as follows:

 

  H+ OH– HCO3– CO3–2 cT
1958 5.6304 8.3696 5.6312 10.3008 4.8774
2015 5.5787 8.4213 5.5793 10.3006 4.7824

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the syntax of the MATLAB function fsolve?

worksheet.stem:
The following system of five nonlinear equations govern the chemistry of rainwater:

 

%media:formula127.mml%

 

%media:formula128.mml%

 

%media:formula129.mml%

 

%media:formula130.mml%

 

%media:formula131.mml%

 

where KH = Henry’s constant, K1, K2, and Kw = equilibrium coefficients, cT = total inorganic carbon, (HCO3−) = bicarbonate, (CO 3−2) = carbonate, (H+) = hydrogen ion, and (OH−) = hydroxyl ion. Notice how the partial pressure of CO2 shows up in the equations indicating the impact of this greenhouse gas on the acidity of rain. Use these equations and the fsolve function to compute the pH of rainwater given that KH = 10−1.46, K1 = 10−6.3, K2 = 10−10.3, and Kw = 10−14. Compare the results in 1958 when the %media:formula132.mml% was 315 and in 2015 when it was about 400 ppm. Note that this is a difficult problem to solve because the concentrations tend to be very small and vary over many orders of magnitude. Therefore, it is useful to use the trick based on expressing the unknowns in a negative log scale, pK = −log10(K). That is, the five unknowns, cT = total inorganic carbon, = bicarbonate, carbonate, (H+), (OH−), (HCO3−), (CO3−2), and cT can be reexpressed as the unknowns pH, pOH, pHCO3, pCO3, and pcT as in

 

%media:formula133.mml%

 

%media:formula134.mml%

 

%media:formula135.mml%

 

In addition, it is helpful to use optimset to set a stringent criterion for the function tolerance as in the following script you can use to generate your solutions.

 

clc, format compact
xguess = [7;7;3;7;3];
options = optimset('tolfun',1e−12)
[x1,fx1] = fsolve(@funpH,xguess,options,315);
[x2,fx2] = fsolve(@funpH,xguess,options,400);
x1',fx1',x2',fx2'

(Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The pH of rain-water is as follows:

 

  H+ OH– HCO3– CO3–2 cT
1958 __a__ __b__ __c__ __d__ __e__
2015 __f__ __g__ __h__ __i__ __j__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The function along with the suggested script is as follows:

 

function f = funpH(x,pCO2)
% 10^(-x(1))=H, 10^(-x(2))=OH, 10^(-x(3))=HCO3, 10^(-x(4))=CO3, 10^(-x(5))=cT
KH=10^(-1.46); K1=10^(-6.3);K2=10^(-10.3);Kw=10^(-14);
f = [10^6*10^(-x(1))*10^(-x(3))/(KH*pCO2)-K1;...
     10^(-x(1))*10^(-x(4))/10^(-x(3))-K2;...
     10^(-x(1))*10^(-x(2))-Kw;...
     (KH*pCO2)/1e6+10^(-x(3))+10^(-x(4))-10^(-x(5));...
     10^(-x(3))+2*10^(-x(4))+10^(-x(2))-10^(-x(1))];

clc, format compact
xguess=[7;7;3;7;3];
options=optimset('tolfun',1e-12)
[x1,fx1] = fsolve(@funpH,xguess,options,315);
[x2,fx2] = fsolve(@funpH,xguess,options,400);
x1',fx1',x2',fx2'

 

Output

 

ans =
    5.6304    8.3696    5.6312   10.3008    4.8774
ans =
   1.0e-08 *
    0.0000   -0.0000   -0.0000   -0.1069    0.0038
ans =
    5.5787    8.4213    5.5793   10.3006    4.7824
ans =
   1.0e-09 *
    0.0000   -0.0000   -0.0000   -0.7908    0.0157
